Award.AwardTitle: 2017 Chemical Engineering Summer School - The Future is Today; July 29-August 3, 2017; North Carolina State University

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Engineering Division of the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) will hold its 16th Chemical Engineering Summer School from July 29-August 3, 2017 at North Carolina State University. The Summer School has been the premier faculty development workshop for new chemical engineering faculty since 1931. In order to provide maximum benefit to the faculty, this workshop is offered every five years. The Summer School is unique in its emphasis on the development of new chemical engineering educators. By targeting faculty within their first five years of their careers, professors can become more effective at all facets of their job as educators and ultimately produce better prepared undergraduate and graduate chemical engineering professionals.

At the 2017 Chemical Engineering Summer School, new faculty will learn best practices in effective teaching, including active learning techniques. The instructors are leaders in chemical engineering education. Furthermore, the participants will also learn about technical (such as safety, sustainability, computational fluid dynamics, process modeling, and emerging topics within the discipline) and non-technical topics (such as communication skills, leadership, ethics, etc.) Historically, around 200 chemical engineering educators, many of whom are within the first five years of their initial faculty appointment and others who are returning as instructors, attend the Summer School. The new educators are able to form strong partnerships with their peers who are in similar stages of their careers. In addition, they meet and interact with senior chemical engineering faculty and receive critical advice on career development matters. To foster interactions, the participating faculty present a poster about their research and education activities at their home institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report

2017 Chemical Engineering Summer School: The Future is Today; July 29 – August 3, 2017; North Carolina State University

NSF Award Number: 1703951

 

  • The Chemical Engineering Summer School was the highest attended summer school ever, with 242 registered attendees. This group included 171 junior faculty members in the first five years of their appointments.
  • Financial support was provided by the National Science Foundation, Chevron, ExxonMobil, and International Paper.  
  • Attendees learned new methods to teach their courses effectively
    • Teaching Institute on Saturday, Conducted by Rich Felder and Rebecca Brent.
    • Plenary talks by Phil Wankat, Nicholas Peppas, Tony Go / Buddy Lang, and TJ “Lakis” Mountziaris.
    • Informal interaction with new and experienced faculty.
    • Experiences faculty taught 38 unique sessions in areas including:
      • LabVIEW and Data Acquisition as a Problem- Solving and Design Tool in Chemical Engineering
      • Learn Aspen Plus™ in 24 Hours: A Modular Approach to Teaching Process Simulation
      • Methods and Tools to Help Students Learn Core ChE Concepts
      • New Faculty Career Development
      • Scale Up: Tools and Tips for Teaching a Large Class
      • Students Are People Too – Tips on Advising
      • Taking it to the Next Level...Game-Based Learning in ChE
      • Teaching Across the Chemical Engineering Curriculum with Food!
      • Teaching Process and Product Design
      • Unit Operations Laboratory
      • Updating the Process Controls and Dynamics Course for the 21st Century
      • Using Arduino Microcontrollers in Your Classroom or Laboratory
      • What are NSF Broader Impacts? How does this fit into teaching and outreach?
    • A post-conference, three-level Likert scale survey was conducted and key results were:
      • Significantly impacted 67% of attendees teaching
      • Significantly impacted or impacted 99% of attendees teaching
      • Significantly impacted or impacted 58% of attendees research
      • Significantly impacted or impacted 67% of attendees professional service
      • The conference committee was surprised by these last two results. The junior faculty attendees formed research relationships and with each other and with senior faculty (some won grants together or felt that they were more competitive for grants based upon what they learned), and were inspired to increase their level of service to the community and their involvement with the American Society for Engineering Education and the American Institute of Chemical Engineers
